COVID-19 Update #6
Dear Silver Lake Community:

This afternoon, Governor Baker announced that all Massachusetts schools must remain closed until at least Monday, May 4th. We know this has a significant impact on our families, but the Governor explained that extended closures are necessary to slow the spread of coronavirus.

Commissioner of Education Jeff Riley also spoke at the briefing, and explained that the Dept. of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE) will be providing updated guidance to assist schools as they get distance learning opportunities underway for students. We will update you on any changes to our distance learning plan after we receive additional guidance from the state.

If your student needs a Chromebook, we have extended the window. Please use this link https://pickatime.com/slrsd/chromebook to set up a time to pick up a device.

Our teachers continue to work together to design learning experiences that will keep students learning, engaged, and connected to one another. And remote learning just doesn’t mean online learning. We hope to design experiences that will help students learn in authentic ways and discover new interests and passions. Students learn in so many ways, and we are working to make sure we properly value how they learn with technology, with people, and with their hands. Doing this all from a distance is a challenge, but we want you to know what our priorities are as we support staff in their work to keep students learning.

We know the way forward will not be easy, but we know we can get through it by focusing on our students and working together to do the best we can to meet their needs.

Jill Proulx and Ryan Lynch

 
Helping Families Cope
Dear Families,

Attached please find strategies from Dr. Maria Trozzi, Former Assistant Professor of Pediatrics, Boston University School of Medicine.


Her recommendations include what families CAN do to cope during this difficult time.


Sincerely,

Jill Proulx and Ryan Lynch

Attachment: Coping Strategies
 
COVID-19 Update #5

Dear Communities,

Per the request of our towns, all playgrounds and athletic fields are closed due to social distancing and surface area contamination concerns until further notice.

This includes playgrounds on our school campuses.

Thank you for your anticipated cooperation,

Jill
 

Learning Resources and Chromebook Loaners
Dear Silver Lake Community:

With schools in Silver Lake, Halifax, Kingston, and Plympton closed for the next three weeks, we want to do whatever we can to keep students connected to learning, especially since so many of our daily routines have had to change. 

To support students and help them stay connected to their learning over the period of the school closure, we have compiled the learning resources below.

Silver Lake K-6 Learning Resources (Click Here)
Silver Lake 7-12 Learning Resources (Click Here)

These resources have been pulled together by our curriculum coordinators, program directors, principals, and teachers; and they deserve thanks for assembling high quality resources in such a rapid fashion. We hope these activities and platforms help students to stay connected and learning while school is closed. We know nothing replaces in person instruction, but this is another measure we have to take to make sure we are doing everything we can to slow the spread of Covid-19.

These learning activities are not required and will not be assessed as part of students’ grades. They are meant to provide educational experiences when school is closed.

If you do not have internet access from your home, Comcast is offering free wifi through the following program: https://corporate.comcast.com/covid-19 

During the closure, families can get technology support by emailing distancelearning@slrsd.org or your student’s principal. A member of our staff will get back to you once you send a question or request.

We hope you find these resources helpful to your students for the time being, and we look forward to having students and staff learning together again in person once this situation passes.

Thank you,

Ryan Lynch
Assistant Superintendent
 
Special Education Update
Dear Special Education Community,

As you are aware, the Silver Lake Regional School District will remain closed until at least Monday, April 6th 2020. Our schools remain committed to students and are working to develop resources for families to support ongoing learning opportunities for all learners.

The Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE) has issued the attached FAQ to provide regulatory guidance. A school closure of this nature and this duration is an exceptional circumstance. The DESE has confirmed that schools are not required to provide IEP services to students with disabilities and that there is no expectation to replace all special education services upon return. There is, however, an understanding and concern for potential regression. A break such as this will inevitably result in some regression for all learners. Once students return to school, teams will review the individual nature of a child’s IEP services and assess the significance of regression. Compensatory services will be assessed on a case by case basis. 

For additional information regarding the state’s responsibilities to children with disabilities, please visit: 

https://www.isbe.net/Documents/qa-covid-19-03-12-2020.pdf

The Silver Lake Regional School District will continue to provide updates as we receive guidance from the Massachusetts Department of Education as well as the US Department of Education concerning this unprecedented closing and the opportunities of ongoing learning experiences.


Thank you,

Marie Grable, MA, CAGS, NCSP
Administrator of Special Education

 

COVID-19 Update #4
Dear Silver Lake Community:

This evening, Gov. Charlie Baker announced that all public schools in Massachusetts will remain closed until Monday, April 6th to limit the transmission of the coronavirus. That means that Halifax, Kingston, Plympton, and Silver Lake schools will remain closed until at least Monday, April 6th.

We wanted to share this information with you right away so you can make plans with your family related to this closure.

We recognize that a shutdown of this length has significant impacts on students, staff, and families, and we are working on plans for how we can support students, staff, and families during this time.

Student lunches: Earlier today, we reached out to all families who participate in our free/reduced lunch programs to ask about their needs during the closure and set up “grab and go” lunch pick-ups. If you did not receive the survey but need assistance with student lunches during the closure, please complete this survey or call our Food Services Director, Megan Arenholz at 781-582-3556. At this time, we are developing plans to support only free / reduced lunch students, but will evaluate if we have additional capacity to support other families in need. Representatives from our schools, health agents, Police and Fire will conduct a conference call tomorrow to address the concerns of social distancing and how to best serve our students who are eligible for free / reduced lunch.

Cleaning and Disinfecting of Schools: During the closure, schools will be cleaned and disinfected, so staff cannot be in school buildings during the closure to maintain the disinfected environment. We truly appreciate the efforts of our custodial crews and during this time.

School Calendar: While schools will be closed until at least Monday, April 6th, the Education Commissioner explained that schools need to go only until their 185th scheduled day, so if that guidance remains, that means our last day in Silver Lake would be Friday, June 19th. At this time, there is no state plan to cancel April break.

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":8341,"s":"
Continuity of Education: State Education officials have stated that schools remain committed to students and are working on a plan to maintain learning experiences for students even while schools are closed. These materials cannot replace face-to-face instruction, but we will share resources to try and maintain some momentum in learning. This includes supports for students on individualized education plans (IEPs). Per state guidelines, this work will not be mandatory or formally assessed as part of students’ grades. More guidance will be shared with families as soon as we have formal plans in place, but we want families and staff to know this is a priority. To help us to determine what forms this type of learning may take we ask that you please complete this survey about your student’s access to technology.

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScewrQy1RZHVRb_K1VyhGLlDCNfiQyLNRG9PvYJ71LmUytqCg/viewform?usp=sf_link

MCAS and AP Tests: Both the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE) and The College Board have stated that they are revising testing plans and we will share updates as soon as we have them.

Reminders:

Closure of schools is intended to stop the rapid spread of coronavirus. To ensure that we are limiting transmission, please remember:
All school-related activities and use of school facilities are cancelled during the closure. Elementary principals will announce new updated plans for kindergarten registration. Students should not visit school property and are not encouraged to gather together during the closure. Governor Baker asked families to do their best to stay at home during this time. Following social distancing will help keep our community safe.
Administrators will be working during the closure, so please reach out to Dr. Proulx, Mr. Lynch, Ms. Grable or your student’s principal if you have questions during the closure. Email is the best way to contact us as we are working in ways to limit possible transmission.
Staff and families should continue to monitor email closely for the latest updates from Silver Lake leadership.

We have been grateful and inspired with the flexibility and focus of our staff and students during this challenging time. We will continue to get through this together.

Thank you,

Jill Proulx and Ryan Lynch


 
COVID-19 Update #3
Dear Silver Lake Community:

At 8:30 AM this morning, we participated in a conference call with the MA Commissioner of Education and the MA Commissioner of Public Health. They provided guidance on next steps to deal with the impacts of coronavirus. We also communicated with area district educational leaders to make a plan that is in the best interest of our entire region.

Based on this guidance, we will close the Silver Lake schools for the next two weeks. At this time, the tentative return for students and staff would be Monday, March 30th.

Closing our schools in Halifax, Kingston, Plympton, and Silver Lake for two weeks will allow us to clean and disinfect our schools, mitigate the spread of the virus, and consider additional guidance from the MA Department of Public Health (DPH).

We recognize that this closure has a significant impact on our communities. We must take proactive steps, however, in the best interests of our students and families. Nothing is more important than the health and safety of our students and staff.

During this time, you should report information regarding potential cases or contact with cases to your local Board of Health or the Massachusetts Department of Health at (617) 983-6800. Quarantined individuals who have questions or concerns related to their quarantine should contact DPH or their local health department.

Central office, principals, and essential personnel will continue to work during the closure, so please contact us with any questions or concerns. Email is the best method of contact as we might be moving locations during cleaning.

We recognize schools are essential sources of information for our community, and we will continue to keep families and staff informed during the closure time. We will get through this together.

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":12467,"s":"
Thank you,
Jill Proulx and Ryan Lynch 
COVID-19 Update #2
Dear Community,

We want to keep you updated about the steps we are taking to manage the coronavirus situation and its impact on the Silver Lake community. Yesterday, Governor Baker held a press conference regarding COVID-19.
First, there are no known cases of COVID-19 among students or staff in the district.
In this press conference, the Governor reported the following:
“State Education Commissioner Jeff Riley is strongly urging all districts to cancel all out-of-state travel at this time. This is in addition to the Administration’s existing request for schools to cancel international trips.
The Department of Public Health (DPH) will be issuing updated guidance to Superintendents on how to address cases that arise at a school, including potential school closures."
In line with the Governor’s recommendation, we will be cancelling all out of state field trips. We have asked our principals to work with those groups affected to help answer questions that will arise as a result, including the possibility of rescheduling, refunds, etc. We recognize cancelling is disappointing, but it is necessary for schools to follow state guidance to limit the possible spread of the virus.
The Governor made other recommendations about large group gatherings and people at higher risk in the community. The Superintendent will attend a conference call with the Education Commissioner and the Department of Public Health (DPH) on Thursday afternoon. The hope is to obtain clear and explicit guidance about how this may impact upcoming events for schools.
At this time school events for students and staff will continue. This is a rapidly evolving situation and we will work with our staff to make decisions as quickly as possible and to communicate those details. Please understand that it is our goal to educate and care for students on a daily basis, and we will safely try to keep our routines in place so that students can learn and be supported. In the face of new information from state and health agencies, we recognize that we may need to reassess what form this will take in the coming days and weeks.
We are working with our building principals, school nurses, our school physician, local boards of health and government agencies on a daily basis to provide guidance and to implement safeguards. 
Below are the steps we have taken in all of our schools:
Cleaning and Disinfecting:
Custodial and school staff have increased cleaning and disinfecting of common surfaces, including desktops, door handles, counter-tops, and railings.
Our buses and vans are cleaned and disinfected on a daily basis following the department of health guidance.
Getting Expert Guidance on Limiting Transmission and Tracking:
We obtained an updated standing order with our Silver Lake physician about the importance of students staying out of school when they exhibit symptoms like fever, coughing, etc. The order explains that students who have a fever may not return to school until 24 hours of being fever free without anti-pyretics (i.e. Tylenol/Motrin). Attached is the letter.
School nurses have developed a form to be used to track symptoms and potential absences and potentially update health officials.
Schools continue to emphasize the critical importance of hand washing and other healthy habits.
Planning Flexibility for Students:
We have asked principals to support flexible attendance for students.
Principals have asked staff to consider ways to educate students if students are out for a period of time.
Talking to Your Student: The unfolding health situation is raising worry and anxieties for many of us, and we share these resources in hopes that they will be helpful in conversations within our community. Students look to adults and caregivers in times of worry, and you can support students at home by sharing facts and helping them manage.
Share facts about COVID-19 (CDC)
Stigma & Resilience (CDC)
Helping children cope with emergencies (CDC)

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":16486,"s":"Ultimately, this is a public health situation, and the guidance of state and federal agencies must be followed. While conditions and guidance can change, please comply with directives from the state and federal government. We will communicate any changes or updates as soon as we have them.

Sincerely,
Jill Proulx and Ryan Lynch 

Attachments: District Physician Letter 
COVID-19 Update #1
To the Communities of Halifax, Kingston and Plympton,

In an effort to ensure student health and wellness, we are sending home information regarding the coronavirus and the flu. Please find three copies attached to this email with up to date information regarding the coronavirus and the flu. 

In addition, the Department of Public Health and the Department of Education (DESE) have provided the following information for schools: 

https://www.smore.com/b9u7a

With the CDC's updated recommendations, the Board of Health, and our nurses, we will continue to discuss any updates to our existing sickness protocols, to monitor documented cases of the flu (and other viruses should they arise), and to monitor school attendance. 

As a reminder, we are currently considered low risk for the coronavirus. Please check the CDC.gov website for the most recent information. 

Please review the following precautions: 
Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, if unable to wash, use alcohol-based hand sanitizers
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth
Cover your coughs or sneezes with a tissue or your sleeve (not with your hands)
Stay away from people who are sick and stay home when you are sick

Any student who presents with fever or flu like symptoms, should stay home, until they are fever and symptoms free with no medication for 24 hrs. Parent(s) should contact your child's physician with any questions or concerns.

Sincerely, 
Dr. Jill A. Proulx
Attachments: Flu Guide for Parents, Pandemic Flu, Sick with 2019 nCoV Fact Sheet
